This debate today has nothing to do with whether or not the Australia Card is right or wrong; whether this ID card is good or bad, at least from the Government's point of view. This debate is about the Government's cynicism in re- introducing to this chamber legislation it knows to be flawed and which it is too disreputable to repair because its intentions today are not to try to get this card rejected by the Senate-because that is what the objective really is-because it is a bit of failed legislation; it wants it rejected in exactly the same terms as before. If the Government were fair dinkum it would have amended the legislation. It clearly is not fair dinkum. The Age says:

The Government had been prepared to make the amendments suggested by the banks before Cabinet decided that it would prefer to present an unaltered bill before Parliament so that its likely rejection in the Senate would give the Government a trigger for a double dissolution.
It is not just me making this point. I am saying what is recognised widely throughout the community: This Government's behaviour is totally dishonourable in this matter. The Age continued:
A submission to the Government last month said that without amendments the banks would not be able to incorporate use of the card into its systems in line with the Government's timetable.
It said that a number of technical aspects of the Bill needed amendment before the card could be used in the banking system.

The director of the bankers' association, Mr Alan Cullen, said yesterday that the legislation made some unrealistic assumptions. The banks had not disagreed with the identity card on principle, they had only pointed out the many problems for banks with the present legislation.

Then he added that the card's introduction would cost the banks between $60m and $70m in setting up costs and about $5m a year to run. That is on top of the incredible costs of this card to the community at large. The banks stressed that they were not becoming involved in this debate on a political level. The Australian Bankers Association said in a submission that was rejected and ignored by this Government, at least in terms of the Association's attitude to this Bill as it returns, that it neither opposed nor supported the Australia Card because it had not been able to evaluate the wider aspects, which go far beyond the identification of bank transactions. However, the banks were concerned at the operational aspects of the scheme. Some of those concerns are natural self-interest; nonetheless, they are worth recognising.

For example, penalties in those parts of the Bill that concern banks fall almost wholly on the financial institution. The penalty in every case is $20,000 and is expressed so as to be applicable to each offence. A simple error or omission, says the banks' submission, could lead to multiple `offences' with resultant larger accumulation of penalties. With the millions of accounts to be accessed, and the Australia Card number and other details as required recorded thereon, it is inevitable that errors in recording will occur. Banks seek mitigation of the penalties or none at all in cases of error where there was no intention to assist a customer to evade the restrictions intended by the legislation. Let us recognise that it is not the banks that would be guilty of doing something disgraceful. This relates to a procedure which is supposed to supervise, in effect, the activities of a dishonest operator in the market-place. Yet the banks face a $20,000 penalty for making a technical mistake. This Government is too arrogant to consider amending this legislation in an appropriate way but returns it in its original flawed state to this place.

Let us look at the problem of dishonoured cheques being presented for payment. The banks say that because of the impact of dishonoured cheques and many other matters relating to cheques the Australia Card legislation will result in a marked reduction in the availability and convenience of banking services for the community. The effect on ordinary Australians of the Bill as it now stands will be a marked reduction in the availability and convenience of banking services to the community and an undermining of confidence in the use of periodical payment and direct entry systems, particularly for salary and social security-in other words, payments made directly to one's account. According to the Australian Bankers Association, there will be an undermining of confidence in those arrangements because of the way the Bill now stands and a possible reluctance within the community to accept cheques as a form of payment. Obviously, this will push more and more people into using cash. This is just a nonsense if we are to push people into having more and more cash transactions because of the impact of this legislation on the willingness of people to accept cheques.

These points, I believe, are very serious and the consequence of this, as the banks' submission says, would push society much more heavily towards the use of cash without utilisation of banking facilities or the resultant records of financial transactions. What happens if we push people more into cash? This very legislation, if it pushed people more into the use of cash, would push them more into the black economy, even more into the area where there is no adequate taxation cover and where the Australia Card will do nothing-as has been accepted by all the expert advice-to limit tax evasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true.

—The honourable senator opposite says that it is not true. I do not mind if Senator Richardson describes the Australian Bankers Association as containing people who tell things that are untrue-which I suppose is another word for an unparliamentary word-but if Senator Richardson has that opinion of the Australian Bankers Association, that is his business. But if that attitude is spread throughout the Government it might explain why this Government does not understand and has not taken proper cognisance of the very real concerns raised by a very significant and competent body in this area. If Senator Richardson, from the depth of his experience of running a right wing political machine in New South Wales, knows that the Australian Bankers Association is wrong, I congratulate him. He obviously has much greater contact with banking than I thought. I often wondered what went on in the New South Wales right wing of the Australian Labor Party. Obviously, it is much more involved in banking than in running a political party which is supposed to represent the workers. I simply say that if Senator Richardson is trying to take comfort out of the fact that this is wrong I would appreciate his outlining when the Australian Bankers Association is wrong in this area.
—The Minister did not think it was wrong.

—That is exactly right. The reality is that in so many of these areas the Minister has agreed that there is a need for amendment. The Government had agreed that there was a need for amendment. The Age newspaper reports that the Government was prepared to make the amendments suggested by the banks.
—That is just not true.

—Senator Richardson says that it is not true. I do not mind if Senator Richardson describes the Australian Bankers Association as an organisation which says things that are not true, which I suppose is an unparliamentary word. If Senator Richardson has that opinion of the Australian Bankers Association, that is his business and it might explain why, if that attitude is spread throughout the Government, this Government does not understand, and has not taken proper cognisance of, the very real concerns raised by a very significant and competent body in this area. If, from the depth of his experience of running a right wing political machine in New South Wales, Senator Richardson knows that the Australian Bankers Association is wrong, I congratulate him. He obviously has much greater contact with banking. I often wondered what went on in the New South Wales right wing of the Labor Party. Obviously it is much more involved with banking than with running a political party which is supposed to represent the workers. If Senator Richardson is trying to take comfort out of the fact that this report is wrong, I would appreciate his outlining where the Australian Bankers Association is wrong in this area.
—The Minister didn't think it was wrong.

—Exactly. The reality is that in so many of these areas the Minister has agreed that there is a need for amendment. The Government had agreed there was a need for amendment. The Age newspaper reports that the Government was prepared to make the amendments suggested by the banks.
—You can't believe what you read in the papers.

—I have not seen an effective denial of this report. If Senator Richardson is saying that the Age newspaper was totally incorrect in reporting that the Government had been prepared to make the amendment wonder how they will feel when they realise that that will be the situation that the Australia Card will present.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to an outline plan prepared for the interdepartmental committee on a national identification numbering system and put to the Cabinet in May 1985 by the Health Insurance Commission. I want to refer to this document because I think it is pretty important that the people of Australia realise just how far this Australia Card can go. The document states:

This preliminary report has been prepared for the IDC on a national identification numbering system (chaired by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet) to provide an outline of how the Health Insurance Commission might establish and operate such a system.
It continues:
It is understood that the principal objective of the system is to establish a facility that would, by uniquely identifying every Australian:
(b) in particular, to prevent or at least reduce the incidence of-incorrect payment of benefits and other government moneys.

The principal objective was not tax evasion. The interdepartmental committee said that the principal objective was `in particular, to prevent or at lease reduce the incidence of incorrect payment of benefits and other government moneys'.

The Government talks emotively about tax evasion and tax cheats. It is beyond my imagination how the Government can have the hide to talk about tax evasion and tax cheats when its own Treasurer (Mr Keating) did not put in his tax returns on time for two years running. He did not put in one tax return for over 12 months and he was late with his next one. But then, the hypocrisy of this Government is quite unsurpassed. The document also said:

. . . it must be emphasised that the plan is simply a statement of how a national identification system might be put in place, as requested by the IDC. It does not represent management's views on the desirability of the Commission undertaking this task.
I do not blame the people who drew up the document for saying that. If I had been asked to do it, I would be covering myself too. The document went on to state:

Labels or acronyms selected even at this early stage tend to become entrenched and it is for that reason that the Commission has not used . . . NINS (National Identification Numbering System) which has unfortunate connotations. A positive name that helps to emphasise the beneficial nature of the system for members of the public is needed. If the system objectives can be defined (for the public) so as to emphasise benefit entitlements (e.g. Medicard and social security) a suitable name might be the Australian Benefit Card-it's as easy as ABC!

Unfortunately, that name was unable to be used because there was no benefit to the Australian people. It was suggested that the Government should put forward a name which did not have bad connotations, such as `national identification numbering system'. It was suggested that we should adopt a name as easy as ABC-the Australian Benefit Card. This is a good argument from the point of view of selling the idea but it falls far short of giving the people of Australia the accurate information that they need and deserve. The document went on:
It will be important to minimise any adverse public reaction to implementation of the system.
How does one go about that? The document continues:

One possibility would be to use a staged approach for implementation, whereby only less sensitive data are held in the system initially with the facility to input additional data at a later stage when public acceptance may be forthcoming more readily.

So the document proposed doing it in easy stages, starting off with just a little bit. Senator Gareth Evans intimated by way of interjection the last time I spoke on this legislation that this would happen. I will refer to that later. The document suggested doing it in easy stages-this year a little bit and next year a little bit more, until finally the people of Australia will more readily accept the whole lot. The document continues:
Other related issues . . . are the extent to which:
(a) the nature of all items of data held on the central database will be made known to the public-
the document talks about the extent to which all the information would be made known to the public, about how much the public would be told-
(b) the names of the government agencies with access to the system will be made public--

We know that this information was given to Cabinet. The document raised the question of what the public would be told. It continues about the extent to which non-government agencies would be permitted access to the system. How many non-government agencies would be permitted access to the system? The document continues:

It seems sensible only to issue cards to adults. However, it is the Commission's view that registration on the system database should be effected for all persons even though cards would not be issued for minors. This approach would:
(a) ensure a comprehensive database covering the entire population;
(b) enable initial registration of newborns to be done automatically . . .
That is, this system would cover people from the cradle to the grave. The document goes on:
It can be expected that, after the system has been implemented and has settled down, the personal identification number would come to be used as a universal identifier.

In other words, after everything has settled down, after people have got used to having an identification number, after people have got used to the fact that they have a number from the cradle to the grave, the number can be used as a universal identifier. The document continues:

In time it might be used as that person's Medicare number, Income Tax file number or even bank account number etc. Overseas experience relating to privacy considerations should be carefully examined to determine the extent to which this practice should be allowed.
The document continues:
The preferred strategy would be one which would:
(b) avoid, or at least minimise, adverse public criticism;
The document continues:

It is envisaged that arrangements would be made . . . to access databases in all participating government agencies i.e. those that hold basic identification data for a significant number of Australians and have a legitimate interest in matching that data against other government records. It is expected that participating agencies would include Medicare, the Australian Taxation Office, Foreign Affairs (Passport Office), Department of Social Security, Department of Veterans' Affairs, Australian Electoral Office, State Registrars of Births, Deaths and Marriages and any other authorities with data suitable for inclusion in the system.
Relevant information from these databases would be extracted and converted to a new standard format on the national identification database to facilitate matching of personal data.
We are told by Senator Tate that this would not occur. We were told, no, that would not happen. What were we told last year? Everyone remembers. We were told:
There will be no capital gains tax.
The Prime Minister said:
Let me make a promise so that even the Opposition can understand--

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean even the Government.

—Yes, so that the Government can understand. That was the time when the Prime Minister said that there would be no capital gains tax. What do we have? We have a capital gains tax. When I said that last time, what was the interjection from Senator Gareth Evans? I read from Hansard. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: One election later.

That promise was not for that election-and we in the Senate are expected to accept this Government's promise that the Australia Card will not be used for all those things that have already been suggested. We are being expected to believe that the Government will not make a decision on the extent to which the items on the general central data base will be made known to the public. We are expected to believe that secrets will not be held-that there will not be things that the public do not know about. What absolute rubbish.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the legislation says.

—That is right. But Senator Tate should not forget that that applies only to this election. That is what Senator Gareth Evans said to me last time. He said: `That promise was only for this election'-not for the next election, not for any election after; that promise was only for this election. There have been no promises of what will happen in the future under this Government-none at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Since we last debated this Bill in the Senate the Australian Bankers Association has come out very strongly saying that credit card transactions will be unworkable. Transfer of funds and cash withdrawals through access to automatic teller machines will not be workable. Electronic fund transfer point of sale transactions-the system of debiting personal bank accounts for supermarket and other purchases-will not be workable. The Minister promised us amendments to fix these things, but because the Prime Minister said `We need it unamended for a double dissolution' it was pushed through the House of Representatives. But before it was able to be pushed through here the Prime Minister changed his mind. He had read the polls and he knew he would not win.

The Government has said that the Australia Card will cover a few things. It would cover social security fraud; it would deal with crime. It said that the cost to the Government would not be all that great. It would not talk about the cost to industry. It said it would deal with tax frauds and there would be no concern at all about privacy. I can assure the Special Minister of State, Senator Tate, that his Government's department has let him down because, during the Estimates hearings, I asked the Department of Social Security whether an identification card would assist it to deal with fraud. It said no. I said: `Explain why it would not'. It said: `Identification is not our problem; it is misstatements that are our problem. An identification card will not deal with that'. I think Senator Crowley must think that the people of Australia are so naive. It is incredible. She tried to convince us today that people would put all the money they earned and did not make statements about in the bank so that it could be picked up there. What absolute rubbish. If people take a part time or full time job and put their hand in for the unemployment benefit, they will not bank it; they will spend it or put it under the bed. They may put it anywhere, but they will not put it in the bank to have it identified. So the Australia Card will not do what the Government says it will do; that is, fix the social welfare fraud. The Department made it very clear that it would not do that.

As far as crime is concerned, the Australian Federal Police have told us that it would have no impact on crime-none at all. Mr Costigan went further and said that in fact it would be quite detrimental. Also, as Senator Michael Baume said today, the New South Wales Department of Transport made it very clear that an ID card photo on a driver's licence would mean only that that person was the person photographed. It would mean nothing else at all-just that that person was the person photographed. But, as Mr Costigan said, it is much worse than that because once one presents an ID card then for all intents and purposes, without further questioning, one is accepted as that person. If one has six identification cards one is accepted in various areas amongst various people as six different people.

We come now to the cost to Government. We know, because the Minister has told us, that there will be 2,150 new public servants. We have been told that that is a fact. According to the interdepartmental plan that I was talking about, for card issues alone, six million visits of 10 minutes were expected per annum. One million inquiries per annum of four minutes are expected, and Dr Blewett says that there would be about $759m in expenditure. We have tried very hard to get from the Government what the cost will be to industry. There has not been an answer. Why not? Has the Government not calculated any figures on what the cost to industry will be? None of us believes that. Indeed, so little do we believe that that the shadow Minister in the other place, Mr James Porter, has dropped me a line saying:

I am continuing to pursue through an FOI application the Government's calculation on the business costs of compliance with the ID Card legislation. Only after I applied to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have I made any headway, however, it could be sometime before details are provided.

So the shadow Minister has been seeking information through the Freedom of Information procedures and has had to appeal-and still we have not got the information that the Government is so carefully hiding. I wonder why. What will the cost to industry be? There have been assertions that the cost will be $2 billion. The Government cannot deny it because it will not tell us what it will be.

We then come to the privacy angle. We have been told that everything will be nice and safe; that it will all be tucked away and nobody will be able to get this information except the proper people. The headline in the National Times of 21 September last year was: `For Sale: Social Security files'. Public servants in Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane had social security files for sale-nice and secure! They were offering information to debt collecting agencies. The article states:

The information would be invaluable for debt collecting agencies because it contains current addresses of millions of Australians, and to credit companies because it contains invaluable information about potential borrowers.

So social security files are for sale-a penny a dozen. The Minister broke a confidence in regard to Medicare when he announced some of the doctors' incomes. The Minister, when cornered, broke Medicare's privacy information. He said that Dr Shepherd was earning $75,000 a year. That is an absolute disgrace, but it proves beyond any shadow of a doubt that public servants are no different from other people in the community, that there are bad apples in every section, and that there are a certain number of public servants who, for gain, will sell information. The Minister for Health, when cornered, will break privacy information and give out information that he can only get from private computer systems.

Medibank Private would share common staff, offices, management and board structures with the Australia Card section. The Australia Card program and the Medicare program will be together. So Medibank Private will also have access to this information because of its location. Any public servant who is a software developer, who goes into private enterprise and has the availability of the password and the account number, would know how to type into the system and would be able to get the required information. The privacy angle is shot to pieces. We really cannot have all of the information that the Government aims to have on every citizen being placed in the hands of people who are as vulnerable as any other group in society.

The last matter that I will raise is that the Government has been talking about tax fraud. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure reviewed the Auditor-General's efficiency audit reports. Its report was entitled `A Taxing Problem'. The Auditor-General pointed out in many sections of the review how inefficient the Australian Taxation Office was, that all of the money that had been given to it for expenditure on computerware had not been spent and that, year after year, it was still doing things manually and inefficiently, and allowing tax evasion to go on. It did not need a computer to work out that Mr Keating had not paid his tax for a couple of years-but then, he only got a letter to remind him that he had not--

TALK.START.PARA: —And a special phone call.

—And a special phone call. He only got a letter and a special phone call. The rest of the citizens in Australia do not get a phone call and a special letter; they get abuse. If the Tax Office would buy the proper equipment, perhaps we would not have the problems that the Government is talking about so freely. I will read one small paragraph on page 18 of the report, because it is indicative of the lot:

SPEECH.PARA: Their database is woefully inadequate. Their computer system, their ability to extract the required data and to be able to interface that data between different systems, is inadequate. They do a lot of manual checking now where, theoretically, they should be able to run two different computer tapes, interface them and get a computer printout. There is that sort of thing that goes on.

It does not occur because of a lack of money. The Tax Office was given the money years ago. Because it is so inefficient and it has not bothered to buy the stuff, it is still doing the work manually. It is just ridiculous to say that an ID card will fix that. There is no way that it will be fixed until the Office does the proper thing.

I refer to a few final points. It will not fix social welfare fraud. The Department told us that very quickly. It will not have an effect on crime. Not only the Australian Federal Police but also Mr Costigan said that it will be detrimental. What is the cost to the Government? Dr Blewett says that it will cost nearly a billion dollars and that 2,150 extra public servants will be required. We do not know what the cost to industry will be. Privacy is out the window.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 2]. As I stand here, noting that I am at least the twentieth speaker in what is presumably a long list of speakers on this card, I am reminded of how Richard Burton must have felt when he became husband No. 8 to Elizabeth Taylor: He knew the task ahead of him; his difficulty was to make it interesting and different.
—And stimulating.

—And presumably stimulating. One ought at the outset to look at what this card-euphemistically called an Australia Card-is intended to do. In essence, it is a licence to live; it is a licence to function; it is a licence for an individual to be an intrinsic part of the Australian economy. Without the card one has nothing. Without an Australia Card one cannot sell or buy primary products, one cannot sell or buy real estate and one cannot buy or sell shares. Without a card, public companies cannot register shares that one might buy and seek to have registered. One cannot conduct transactions at a bank, a building society or a credit union.
—You only have to produce it once to your broker, and then you're right.

—Yes, that is right, but one cannot commence any of those functions without an Australia Card. If what is euphemistically called the Australia Card is taken away, one's identity is taken away and one cannot function in this society. It is put to us that this card is intended to prevent social security and taxation fraud. Of course, it will do neither.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look for a moment at the cash economy-the area which the National Australia Bank, I think, has described as having a ballpark figure of about $12 billion. What will the card do about the cash economy? Absolutely nothing. What about those people who work in bars, restaurants, clubs or pubs, who, quite improperly, of course, draw their wages or their stipend from the till? This card will do absolutely nothing to prevent that. What will it do in regard to those who work under false names? It will simply drive them into the black money market. It will take them into the cash economy. They will do what others have done before them-again, improperly-and simply take their cash from the till. So we see that the Australia Card is not in any way intended or designed to deal with the fundamental problems in the community in respect of tax evasion and social security fraud.

Let me deal with another weakness of the card, that is, its proof of identity and the very source documents which are used to complete the information on the central register. The very reason that the card is being introduced is that it is presumed by the Government that that information which is available presently by way of identification is not adequate and does not have the required integrity, that a birth certificate is not adequate, that a wedding certificate is not adequate, that a driver's licence is not adequate, but that another document is required to demonstrate that a person is who he says he is. Yet the very foundation on which the identity card is to be established, produced and developed is the very documents which are considered by this Government to have such fragility and inadequacy as sources of identification. There are many recorded cases of people having as many as 20 Medicare cards. No panacea has been found to that problem because it is so easy to reproduce these documents.

It is not without significance to note, as was noted in the submission to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, that the Department of Social Security indicates that it intends to require better and more substantial material identification than just an Australia Card. The Australia Card will not be suitable for a citizen of this country to provide to the very department for whom the card is designed as to the person's identity. Further and better material evidence of identity will have to be established. That is the conundrum. The truth is that the card will not be accepted as prima facie evidence of identity by the very department that has the greatest interest in ensuring that it has a clear understanding of who a person is.

The card will not deal with the problem of organised crime. In fact, if I recall correctly, it was Frank Costigan, QC, who in evidence to the Committee suggested that it would give to criminals perfect anonymity behind which they could hide, flourish, grow and prosper.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all in favour of it.
—Of course they are; Senator Archer is right. Because of the card, they will be able to identify themselves as whoever they wish to be for the time being.
—Another brand new industry.

—Of course. With their capacity, skill and cunning they will ensure that the card becomes a protection for them. It is inevitable that it will not be just government departments but society as a whole that will begin to accept the card in absolute terms by way of identification. The criminal element will flourish behind the veneer of respectability that the card provides in respect of their identification. I think that was a real concern expressed by Costigan.

SPEECH.PARA: One can draw the assumption that part of the reason offered to us by the Government for the card is that a significant amount of false identification is leading to false payments by the Department of Social Security. The truth is that on the evidence available false identity represents 0.6 per cent. It seems that overpayments result primarily from clerical errors and unintentional misunderstandings of the terms and conditions of the benefits and the failure of recipients to disclose a change of circumstances. False identity is not a significant source of loss of revenue to the social security and social welfare sectors, and presumably that is why the Department said that it will be of no material financial benefit for it to implement and to use the card.

When one looks at the risk of the card containing inaccuracies, I am reminded of a comment that was made in this debate on the previous occasion by Senator Puplick, as I recall, who pointed out that the Australian Electoral Commission had indicated that there were some 1.2 million corrections or variations to the Australian electoral rolls every year. One can imagine the alterations, variations and changes that would be required on an ID card and the inevitable risk and hazard of those details being incorrect. It seems that the card, according to evidence given to the Joint Select Committee by the Department of Social Security, will provide absolutely no benefit whatever and that it will cost as much to administer the card to cover the small areas where it might yield some advantage as it would, say, by reducing fraud. So in many respects the card is of no benefit to the Department.

As for the claim by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that it would cost $21m to implement and would save in the range of $1,292m, when the figures are carefully examined it seems that it estimated that of the 50,000 illegal immigrants in this country 0.4 per cent were recipients improperly of social welfare benefits. When the Department provided a list of names to the Department of Social Security, it was found without exception that none of those contained in the lists was receiving benefits. In my view, that is a damning indictment and reflection on the confidence, capacity, ability and efficiency of that Department.

I turn to the grave dangers that the system poses for privacy and the freedom of Australians. It is not without significance that individuals are described and categorised as `card subjects' right from the outset. They lose their character, their soul, their individuality-they are suddenly card subjects. It seems a matter that is not of the slightest concern to this Government. For the moment there are some limitations on to whom and to which departments the information will be provided, but I am reminded of a government submission to the Joint Select Committee which referred to possible uses of the Australia Card. The Australian Taxation Office, the Departments of Health, Social Security, Housing and Construction, Education, Veterans' Affairs, Community Services, Employment and Industrial Relations, Foreign Affairs and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, as well as the Australian Institute of Health, the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Australian Federal Police, to name a few, thought that the card would be of some benefit to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right. They do not have access.
—I am not saying that they have got access. I am saying that those departments have said that the information would be very useful to them if they had a choice.
—The Government has said no.
—I know that it said no-no, for the moment.
—It said no.

—It said no, but it was in the present tense. Whatever the ideals for the future may be, the truth is that, as Senator Tate well knows, once these cards are introduced it seems so obvious to a bureaucratic or a civil servant that he says: `If the information is there, why not use it?' It will seem so obvious for this information to be provided to other government departments. Our elected representatives will stand up here in reduced numbers some time in the future protesting about the proposals of the government of the day to make that information available. That government will argue that supplying the information to other departments will make for efficiency, reduced costs, reduced taxes and that the world will be better for it. That is the inevitability of the circumstances in which we find ourselves. I quote from the Government's submission. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government cannot rule out categorically the possibility that at some future date additional uses may suggest themselves as being desirable or essential to meet the emerging problems in taxation, welfare or other areas.
The Government is providing a caveat on its `no for now'. We know what will happen to those caveats. Without question they will be removed in due course.

I turn to my philosophical objections to these obnoxious cards. We have a community and a society based on a legal tradition which gives citizens the opportunity to do whatever they like unless they are constrained by the law. Perhaps that is best illustrated by the ten commandments which are based on a series of `thou shalt nots', indicating that if a thing is not prohibited, it is permissible. Unless something is clearly stipulated as being illegal, it is legal. From this has grown the idea that liberty is not something that is created by governments--

TALK.START.PARA: —At least one of the commandments is not `thou shalt not'. What about `honour thy father and thy mother'.
—Senator Tate, please let Senator Crichton-Browne finish his speech in peace.
—I was delighted by the interjection, Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sorry that I missed it.
—Senator Tate is a very religious man.

—Yes, he certainly is. We now find ourselves in a situation where one's rights, liberties and freedoms are set out by the form of this card. Unless we have a card, unless we have the Government's permission, we do not have the ability to work, to conduct commercial transactions, to buy or sell shares or to buy or sell primary products. It seems to me that that is not something which concerns this Government. Typically, the history of many has been a struggle against the powers of autocrats, bureaucrats, kings, oppressive governments and generals. I suspect that, with the emergence of a more sophisticated type of democracy, we have in part let the memory of those struggles for liberty slip from our minds. We should be very mindful of this because it is so easy for governments in this day and age, on the pretext of efficiency, good government and good management, to suspend the fundamental rights of democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation seems to me to be a product of a political party whose majority has no care or concern for the intrinsic rights of individuals within society. This legislation comes from a group within a political party whose majority no longer has a soul, a heart, or a belief in the rights of the individual. It makes economic judgments without regard to the effect of those judgments on individuals, their rights, their liberties, their freedoms and their capacity to function. Economics becomes an end in itself rather than a means to enlarge, improve and give growth to that liberty and freedom. It is sad that the repository of integrity for concern for the individual within the Australian Labor Party is now the small core of left-wing members; they are the bastions and final supporters of the rights of individuals. They are not prepared to compromise themselves for political expediency in the pursuit of a few dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that you are not supporting the Halfpennys of this world.

—No, I am not supporting them; they just happen to be supporting a view that we have put forward over decades. The Australian Labor Party also used to accept and embrace this view. Now that it is in government that has all been suspended. It has the hard heads, the pragmatists. It has the numbers who believe that it is more important to be efficient and to chase the dollar that they see in the distance than to provide the people with essential freedom. The Labor Party now believes that a government can subjugate or suspend the basic rights of the individual whom it pretends to represent.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is a crude and misguided lunge at a mirage of money, at an illusion. That is shown by the very example that I have given in terms of the amount of money that is lost to government as a result of false identification, by dishonest representation-0.6 per cent of all revenue lost and that could be recovered by a more efficient taxation system and a more efficient Australian Taxation Office. It will not be recovered by imposing on the total community a system which gives citizens a licence to function, to live-a system without which a citizen cannot function. It seems that this Government has aborted all the fundamental principles that it pretended to have in the past. Besides being oppressive, this legislation is heavy fisted and ham handed. It is a diabolical intrusion-in the real sense of that word-into the rights and lives of the citizens of this country. I do not believe that I have heard one speaker on the Government side even express a concern, a reservation or an anxiety about the trampling of this legislation on the citizen's basic rights, liberties and freedoms. I have not heard anyone on the Government side express the slightest concern or care that this legislation will visit upon the community a rigid strait-jacket of a system by which it must function and with which it must conform. There will be no place in society for those who do not conform.

I ask honourable senators to remind themselves what would happen to any individual who had his card withdrawn for any length of time. If one thinks about that one realises that at the end of the day that is the level of intrusion, the level of the imposition upon the individual. Honourable senators should remember that without a card one cannot buy, sell, borrow, receive, earn or be employed. Not one of those things can be done without a card. That is what this card intends and that is the extent to which this Government is prepared to go, rather than deal with the problem in a practical and obvious way. As I said before, it is prepared in this ham-fisted and heavy-fisted way to impose this diabolical card on our whole society, a card which forever and a day will inhibit the activities and the rights of all individuals. Of course as time goes on, the collection of the information which will be stored in a central computer will be made available to more government departments and to more civil servants. No doubt, at the end of the day, for the right amount of money a pimply 18-year old civil servant will press a button and a computer will spew out the most intimate personal details of individuals within society; yet there is not a care or a concern felt by this Government.
I hope that this legislation is defeated and defeated properly and quickly and that it is cast out of this Parliament and that we are not visited by it again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me continue my contribution to this debate with the following quotation:

SPEECH.PARA: There are cheaper and more effective ways of coping with the problem that arises from tax evasion and tax avoidance.

These were the words of Frank Costigan, QC, who is probably this country's foremost authority on organised crime. He made this comment when referring to the Hawke Government's proposal to introduce a national identity card. Other groups that have not endorsed the identity card proposal include the Department of Social Security, the Australian Federal Police, the Law Society of New South Wales, emeritus Professor Martyn Webb of the University of Western Australia, and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, to name but a few. The Joint Committees of Public Accounts, which I remind the Senate is an all party committee and which in fact it has a majority of Australian Labor Party members on it, examined the social security fraud matter something like two years ago. In its conclusions the Committee actually dismissed the idea of an identity card as being able to rectify the problems in the area of fraud in an efficient way, and said that another or alternative approach would be much more desirable. I remind the Senate that this was the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the largest committee of the Parliament, and a committee that is most concerned about fraud maximising revenue from illegitimate sources. In fact the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card also recognised that such an ID card was not necessary. Even if we go across the waters to the United States of America, we find that studies on the imposition of a national identity card concluded with the comment that:
Organised crime would take advantage of any national identity system because of the presumption of validity surrounding such a system.

Now, faced with two parliamentary reports, faced with comments from distinguished lawyers investigating organised crime, such as Frank Costigan and Douglas Meagher, QC, and faced even with disunity within its own ranks and severe criticism from the national and State Council of Civil Liberties, faced with I think overwhelming national opposition to an identity card, faced with reports from overseas countries rejecting national identification card systems and faced with the plain and simple fact that it is actually wrong, the Hawke Government nevertheless continues to ignore this chamber's previous decision not to put this foolish and ill-considered proposal into the statute books.

I think it is unfortunate that we are pursuing this legislation in the knowledge that even if it does pass, there are going to be amendments in the future. At one stage the Government was prepared to bring in an amended Bill to recognise many of the shortcomings of a Bill which has already passed the House of Representatives and a Bill which the Government hopes to pass in the Senate. A number of bodies will be affected by this proposed identity card legislation and the Government has not taken their advice. In time it will be forced to recognise some of the unintended consequences of this Bill and it will be forced to put before this House, if the Bill passes, amending legislation. I believe that we have enough examples of ill-considered legislation passing through this chamber, and shortly after having to be substantially amended. I submit that if this Bill passes the Senate it will be required to undergo further massive amendment to avoid, as we have so often found with legislation introduced by this Hawke Government, its unintended consequences.

I hope that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, are not one of the Fabian elements in the Australian Labor Party because I think this Bill is an insidious example of perhaps this Fabian element actually tightening its grip and forcing out the moderates to what I believe is to the great long term-not the short term-detriment of the Labor Party. I believe there are very few in favour of this identity card system, except this present Federal Government which is really so keen to try to stoke up the furnaces of a burgeoning bureaucracy and which has very little interest in the protection and privacy of ordinary individuals.

The Hawke Government has put forward what we call this insidious identification card system, which is euphemistically named the Australia Card and which is coloured green and gold, our national colours. If ever there was manipulation of patriotism, the naming and the colouring of this card must take the cake. We are all justifiably proud of the colours green and gold when our athletes go to the Commonwealth Games and the Olympic Games. We find that these colours have been insidiously selected and therefore our patriotism has effectively been manipulated by this Government by the colouring and the naming of this card.

The fact of the matter remains that the identification card will unfortunately not be a foolproof method for establishing identity, for the following reasons: Guidelines established for the issue of cards will not stop the creation of false identities. I believe this to be one of the great weaknesses of the card, apart from a number of onerous impositions that it places on people, organisations and businesses. In order to be listed on the Australia Card Register an individual must produce at least one of the following sound documents as proof of identity: An original birth certificate, a passport, a marriage certificate, a citizenship certificate or apprenticeship papers. We are really getting down the line with apprenticeship papers. Honourable senators can therefore well understand that the value to be placed on such documentation-on any one of these-depends on one or more people telling the truth. It is as simple as that. It would not be an extraordinary obstacle for someone wishing to establish a false identity to obtain, for argument's sake, another person's birth certificate or apprenticeship papers. In some cases the provision of personal details, such as name, year of birth and parents' names, together with reasonable explanations for requiring it, will obtain another person's birth certificate. Having presented such fraudulently acquired documentation, an application for an Australia Card can therefore be made. The Government's claim that the photograph, signature and digitalised strip will make the card hard to forge, has no bearing on the fact that the card can be obtained in the first instance on the basis of fraudulent information. I believe that this is one of the weaknesses. Having obtained the card in such a manner, in such fraudulent circumstances, the individual would be in possession of what then can be regarded as proof of his or her identity. In such cases the Australia Card will really legitimise the illegitimate, given that it will be the public expectation that these cards will provide guaranteed proof of identity.

The provision under clause 36 of the Bill for the use of certificates of identity as substitutes for the card also opens avenues for fraudulent representation of identities. The use of such a certificate will mean that a piece of paper, which does not have the security devices of the card and which shows only what purports to be a particular person's signature, may be used for identification purposes. As can well be imagined, the possibilities of producing forgeries under these circumstances will be great, and their existence will greatly undermine the alleged value of the identity card in providing sound proof of identity.

The visitor ID card is another area where false identification may occur under the system, and I think this is one of the shortfalls. As a number of my colleagues will obviously be aware, the identity cards will be issued to anyone entering the country for a period in excess of six weeks. As photographs and relevant information are not to be obtained at the point of arrival, certain risks of falsification are inherent in such a process. There is no obligation to return a visitor's ID card on leaving the country. I believe that a scenario which could quite easily be imagined even at this time is that a person, having visited Australia and obtained a visitors identification card, could easily hand it to a friend of similar appearance, who then enters the country under a false identity. Despite the Government's stringent claims of the soundness of the card, the creation of false identities will be quite possible. Given that the aim of the legislation is to establish an accurate national system of identification, the many opportunities that really exist for falsification of identity greatly undermine the whole foundation on which this legislation before us rests today.

Let us now look at some of the costs which will be involved. They simply do not equate to the supposed benefits which will flow from it. As we said before, there are cheaper and more effective solutions to dealing with the problems of tax avoidance, social welfare fraud and illegal immigration which the identification card legislation purports to answer. The problem is that this Hawke Government refuses these alternatives in its rush to implement a policy that presents the very real possibilities of the invasion of the privacy of all Australians.

What about the cost to government of the Australia Card proposals? The original estimate was put at $1,046m over 10 years. This figure was quickly revised downwards to $733m. Whatever figure we are to accept is nearer the mark, it must be remembered that cost estimates have an uncanny tendency to blow out. My colleagues who have attended Estimates committee meetings this week would be well aware of this, as would anybody who has looked at a government proposal involving a major capital acquisition. The Government's Australia Card proposal would involve the employment of in excess of 2,150 new public servants. I wonder how this really fits in with Prime Minister Hawke's pledge this week to slash spending in 1987-88 to demonstrate his Government's commitment to fiscal restraint. Existing Medicare branch offices will have to be upgraded and 42 new offices will have to be opened. All this is being done, I suppose, in the name of fiscal restraint. I believe this notion fits rather uneasily.

Many costs have been omitted from the Government's estimates. There has been no allowance for the replacement in this time frame of capital equipment, and no costs are included for private sector compliance. We now have a private sector that is already reeling under the heavy burden of taxation which this Government has forced upon it. As we see from the bankruptcy and solvency figures, many businesses are already going to the wall and many others are operating under very marginal conditions at the moment. All these additional costs could well prove to be the straw that broke the camel's back for many of these businesses that are finding it difficult at the moment. Yet we are still asked to accept this proposal as a solution to the many economic woes which have been brought upon the Australian people by this Hawke Government.

Let us look at some of the benefits. As the costs of implementation of the scheme are a matter for some dispute, so too are many of the alleged benefits. Most of the expected revenue is to be gained from tightening up on tax evasion. However, if we further examine this, revenue estimates relating to the expected gains from the implementation of the Australia Card received from the Australian Taxation Office are highly questionable. It has been revealed that these estimates were made on a qualitative assessment of how tax evaders operate. On this premise I ask therefore: Is this a sound foundation upon which to base our estimates? The answer must surely be no.

Instead of wasting valuable resources on bringing the Australia Card into operation, the Government should be taking up some of the recommendations of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the report of the Senate Select Committee on an Australia Card. Having set up this expensive Committee, the Government should be taking up its very important recommendations. I will refer to some of them. There should be greater communication between banks and relevant law enforcement agencies about suspected fraudulent activity and more efficient use of the wealth of information that the Tax Office already has in its possession. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure has already drawn attention to a lot of techniques that are not being used in order to maximise collections in a number of areas, including failure to check on group certificates.

A third recommendation was the introduction of up to date technology designed to counter tax evasion. The 1984 report of the Auditor-General stated that the Australian Taxation Office had failed to take advantage of technological advances available to it in minimising tax evasion. In other words, the Auditor-General has acknowledged that the Tax Office is not using all the avenues within its power or taking advantage of all the technological resources to ensure that maximum collections are made, particularly from those people who are trying to minimise or evade their tax obligations. There should be stricter rules for identification when opening bank accounts.

All these are very positive measures which could be introduced without the need to implement the Australia Card, with all its attendant buildup in bureaucracy, huge expenditure and civil liberty issues. Similarly, the tightening up of the identification requirements and information update strategies in the Department of Social Security and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs would significantly enhance their ability to cut down welfare fraud. Let us look at the current situation. The Department of Social Security relies on birth certificate extracts, which may be easily obtained by fraudulent means, or in some cases documents such as drivers licences. Must we go from this extreme to the other of issuing every Australian with an identity card to solve these problems? I hope not.

Let us look at another problem. There is no guarantee that the identity card uses which are presently mentioned in this Bill will not be extended. In this identity card legislation I believe we are faced with little more than a wolf in sheep's clothing, something like the Fabian attitude to things. We have nothing more than this Government's doubtful assurances that the Bill's provisions will not be extended. We can remember many of the election promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his subsequent disregard of them. I remind the Senate, for example, of the attitude to capital gains tax and the Prime Minister's disregard for many such assurances.

When faced with this identification legislation many people will doubt the Prime Minister's assurances in this area, too. We could yet see another slick performance which is designed to manipulate public opinion of what is in the best interests of the Prime Minister or the Labor Party. In one of the earliest documents on the Australia Card, the Government was issued a warning by the Health Insurance Commission that many Australians would reject the concept of an identify card. A number of my colleagues have quoted from the Health Insurance Commission's statement and it is important. It says:

It will be important to minimise any adverse public reaction to the implementation of the system. One possibility would be to use a staged approach for implementation, whereby only less sensitive data are held in the system initially with the facility to input additional data at a later stage when public acceptance may be forthcoming more readily.

This advice came from the Health Insurance Commission. Is this legislation at hand the first instalment of a scheme by this Hawke Government to introduce a general purpose national identification system?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—I thank the honourable senator for his assurances. We might hold him to them in a short time. But that is not much use to use. We held the Prime Minister to his assurances that he would not introduce capital gains legislation, but he was not in office very long before this concept of a capital gains tax was introduced. In fact, I remind Senator Evans, as he has interjected, that this capital gains tax is the highest capital gains tax in the world so far as the disposition of a right is concerned, because it taxes us at the maximum marginal rate without any off-set for cost and an inflation adjustment. Despite the honourable senator's assurance that he will not extend this identification card system and the numerals on it to get additional information, one could be forgiven for thinking that he will not be right on this occasion because once this card is implemented the chances of it being extended are very real.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1976, as a response to the growing discontent of the Swedish people with regard to their national identification card, what did the Swedish Government do? It investigated the abolition of the personal identity system but found that the cost was too high. In other words, there was some dissatisfaction even in that advanced democracy of Sweden. This identity card will have 50 separate items of information on every man, woman and child in Australia. Before the Bill was passed like a hot potato from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) it was proposed that 17 authorities would have access to the databanks. Now Dr Blewett has temporarily got this number down to only four. I emphasise that he has temporarily got this number down because, despite the assurances from across the road, it can be-and I believe it will be-easily extended to a greater number or the original 17 or even more than that. As I said, this number could be increased by the stroke of a pen.

We believe that Australia is still a democratic society and in such a free society people should scrutinise the Government-not the Government scrutinising the people. I therefore submit that there is very little in favour of the Bill. It has been acknowledged that five Ministers in the Hawke Government and many of the Labor back benchers oppose the Bill but were forced into line by the rules of Caucus and solidarity. No other Commonwealth country has a similar compulsory national identification system. Those of course are democratic countries, but countries such as Albania, the Soviet Union and East Germany have these sorts of restrictions on personal liberties. The card will be enormously costly. It will be insidious and, despite its proposed name, will be most unAustralian. It is nothing more than a system of computerised surveillance of the Australian people. As such, I believe it should be deplored and soundly rejected again by this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great deal has been said about the Australia Card to date. I want to speak just briefly on some aspects of the debate. I do not think it is necessary to go through all the arguments that have been presented so eloquently by so many of my colleagues up until now. It is true of course that a number of Australians have indicated that they would not mind having an identity card. I can understand that, because most Australians are honest, law-abiding people who feel that to have such a card really would not inconvenience them. But perhaps they have not read the real implications of this legislation. They also feel that it would perhaps help to cut out welfare fraud, tax fraud and illegal immigrants. But in having that view, I suspect that they have not read the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card which has looked into this legislation and has reported to the Parliament. For that reason we need to look at some of the things that have been said and why this again is the Government's glossy response to a problem.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen this so often since those opposite came into government. Priority One was a glossy response to a very real need to combat unemployment, particularly amongst young people. The Drug Offensive was a very glossy and expensive response to a very real problem in our community. It was meant to look as though the Government was doing something. We also had recently the `true blue' campaign. Certainly there is a need to persuade Australians where possible to buy Australian but again this was a glossy response. The card comes into the same category. As long as it looks as though those opposite are doing something, to heck with the consequences and certainly to heck with the expense.

But what about those items that we hear about such as cutting out welfare fraud? The Department of Social Security gave evidence that the ID card proposal would result in no net savings and would be ineffective in tackling the real issue of welfare fraud or the misstating of personal income. That fact needs to be known by everybody in this country. There are ways of getting around social security and there still will be. There is not the slightest doubt that there will be a thriving industry of false identity cards not too long after the first legitimate cards come into operation. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you probably know, a person can go down the street in New York and buy an identity card-any form of identity card which exists. A person can get a card for Princeton or Yale universities. They cost about $US10. That takes about five minutes. It contains the signature of the Vice-Chancellor and has all the supposedly high integrity aspects. It has the person's photograph. A number of those cards are quite valid. We are setting up another potential, flourishing mafia industry in this country. The Joint Committee's report, in relation to welfare and social security, said:

The Government submission reveals that DSS would have no net gain from the introduction of a national identification system. The cost benefit summary indicates that the costs of implementing the Australian Card program equalled the benefits received from the program; that is, $18.2 million over a period of ten years.

There is no real evidence before us that that suggestion has been counteracted or answered. None of us is against dealing with tax frauds but again, I turn to the report of the Committee which states:

. . . the Committee believes that the Australian Taxation Office has available to it powers and information which are not fully utilised, and that there are alternative measures which can also make substantial inroads into tax evasion.

The report goes on to indicate the alternatives which are suggested. After lengthy consideration of the Government's proposal and the arguments and explanations put forward in its support, and with due regard to all the evidence before it, the majority of the Committee opposed the introduction of the Australia Card system. This opposition had two major bases. One was the concern at the effect of a national identification system on the nature of Australian society and the civil liberties of individuals in that society. I can only assume that the Government does not care about those sorts of things. That is not an unreasonable assumption in the light of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill that the Government attempted to force on the community last year. The second basis for opposition was the fundamental doubts as to the cost effectiveness of the proposal and whether it is an appropriate solution to the twin problems of tax avoidance and evasion and the many other fraudulent activities which it claims to cover.

Again, those are all emotive responses, but no real arguments have been put forward which indicate solutions. Perhaps we get most responses about illegal immigrants. Some 60,000 illegal immigrants are in this country at the present time. Evidence was given to the Committee by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and part of it stated:

The Government's submission claims that one of the largest gains to revenue through the introduction of an Australia Card is in the area of the identification of illegal immigrants. The submission notes that over a ten year period the cost to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (DIEA) of implementing an Australia Card program would be $21 million and that the revenue gains over the same period would be $129 million. The basis of the DIEA's estimates is that by requiring employers to sight the Card and quote the employee's Australia Card number when submitting taxation returns, the system, when fully implemented, has the potential to make in-roads into an estimated 60 000 jobs currently being filled by illegal immigrants and visitors working without Departmental authority.

As an aside, it is a bit ironic that when we capture an illegal immigrant as often as not he uses the system to stay in this country and he suddenly becomes entitled to legal aid and such benefits. He uses our legal system to make his presence here different from what it really is. That in itself is a very strange aspect of our immigration policy. This is naive. In any event many illegal immigrants would not file income tax returns. Anybody who sets out to become an illegal immigrant in this country more than likely will have an ID card in his pocket when he gets here. Certainly before too long he would be able to acquire one. I see nothing in this legislation that gives any indication at all as to what one does if one comes across somebody who has an ID card but who it may be suspected is an illegal immigrant. What does one do about that? I would have thought that an ID card would entrench the illegal immigrant system. Once one has a card the likelihood of actually being apprehended or getting into any form of trouble is pretty slim indeed. At the present time the likelihood of getting caught with tax fraud or social security fraud, we are told, is fairly slim. But once a person has this card that proves he is who it states he is, there is no evidence at all to suggest that a system is being established which can challenge such a person. What we are doing is making the whole system much easier for those people who want to work it to their advantage, who want to rip off the system. I see nothing in an ID card that will change that situation.

We have heard that the costs are enormous and there is no reason to believe that they will not be greater than what has been suggested by the Government. However, an aspect of the matter arises from the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills report that I think needs to be answered. That Committee reported to the Senate last year and it has reported again because the Government has not seen fit to make any changes even in areas where it is very apparent that the Government recognises that changes ought to be made. I particularly want to refer to a portion of the Committee's report but I hope the Government will read all of it and take notice of it. It deals with the security of information which comes into the Government's hands. The Committee corresponded with the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and it stated:

The Committee thanked the Minister for this response. While in practice the protection accorded to personal information by the Freedom of Information Act 1982 . . . and the Archives Act 1983 . . . may be no less than that provided for information on the Australia Card Register under the Australia Card Bill 1986, the Committee noted that it was structured differently. Whereas under the Bill only the Card-subject or the prescribed representative of the Card-subject (apart from officials of the Department of Social Security, the Taxation Office and the Health Insurance Commission) were to be entitled to access to the Register, under the FOI Act and the Archives Act there was a prima facie right of public access. The question whether access should be refused on the ground that the document contained information relating to the personal affairs of a person rested to be determined in respect of the FOI Act by the agency or Minister to which the request for access was made . . .

The Committee continued in some detail. It drew our attention to a matter in which there is an area of conflict that needs to be resolved and people who are concerned about it need to know about it. Mr Acting Deputy President, it cannot have escaped your notice that in recent times many petitions have been presented to the Senate by people who have taken the trouble to look into the legislation, who do not want it and who say that it should be opposed. That also needs to be taken into account. Very clearly there is a growing awareness in the community of what this legislation really means and what it will really cost.

I also refer to a letter, a copy of which was sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), by the Australian Computer Society. Dozens of letters have been received by all of us from individuals, and organisations representing many individuals, opposing the ID card. Very few letters-I do not think I have received more than one letter-have suggested that the legislation should be supported. I refer specifically to the Australian Computer Society's representation because that is one group which has some idea of what this legislation is all about and what it can mean. It does not by any means, as honourable senators will hear, take a bigoted approach to the matter. It wrote to the Prime Minister as follows:

This Society submitted to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card that, because of its significant social implications, such a scheme should not be introduced until privacy legislation has not merely been enacted, but has also had sufficient time to be proven . . .
There is a privacy Bill but the Society states that it should not merely be enacted, not merely be around, but it has to be proven. The letter continues:

It appears that Dr Blewett intends proceeding with the proposal in conjunction with, perhaps even in advance of, the long-awaited Privacy Bill. This would conflict with the recommendations of the majority report of the Joint Select Committee, a report which had the support of members of all parties. It would also risk breaching the OECD Privacy Guidelines, an international document which your Government-
the Computer Society is saying this to the Labor Prime Minister-
has ratified.
This Society-
the Australian Computer Society-

is the professional body of the data processing specialists who would implement such a scheme, and is the third largest such professional body in the world. The Society recognises the importance of your Government's attack on the problems of tax evasion, welfare fraud and illegal immigration. However, it draws attention to the existence of alternatives, such as those contained in the parliamentary committee's report.

The Society strongly urges your Government to restore the natural order of events. It should enact the privacy legislation first, then establish the Data Protection Authority, and only consider the proposal for an Australia Card within that protective framework.
The Government should not consider the legislation at all; it should be rejected.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like briefly to address three important aspects of the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 2] which is now before the Senate. I will look at the costs and savings associated with the card, the gross intrusion into people's lives that will result from its introducion and how it just will not do what the Government claims it will do. Firstly, with regard to costs, the Government continues to claim that the Australia Card will be effective in combating tax evasion and welfare fraud. The Opposition has repeatedly said that it will support any reasonable measure that will achieve these objectives, but the card would not do so. The Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, which investigated the proposal, said it would not; the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure entitled `A Taxing Problem' indicates that it would not; and five reports of the Auditor-General prove that it would not.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has claimed that the cost of introducing the Australia Card is about $760m. But, as we all know, by the time anything a government establishes is up and running, the costs will be far in excess of that figure and realistically we can expect the figure to be at least $1 billion. As pointed out by previous speakers, especially those on the Opposition side, the cost to business will be far greater than that. I acknowledge that Government members also have not overlooked that there will be a massive cost to business. Using the 2:1 ratio put forward by the Government's business regulation review unit-and I accept that ratio as appropriate-we can see that the cost to private industry will be at least double the government cost of $1 billion-that is, $2 billion. That makes a total cost to government and private business of $3 billion.

It must also be recalled that the proposal will involve the employment of an additional 2,000 public servants and the upgrading or creation of more than 300 Medicare offices. At the same time, the Government expects to make savings of up to an average of $540m a year each year for the first 10 years of the operation of the card. On this basis, and given the setting up cost of $3,000m for government and private industry, no net saving can be expected until the sixth or seventh year of operation of the identity card. But there are reservations that these apparent net savings will not arise even after 10 years, if ever. There is no reliable basis on which we in the Senate can be assured that net savings will arise at any stage of the operation of the Australia Card as set out in this legislation. For example, last year Roger Clarke, a reader in information technology at the Australian National University, made a submission to the Joint Select Committee in which he examined the Government's costing. He found:
The means whereby the arguments give rise to the figures, and the assumptions and estimating bases underlying them are not provided.

So no plausible foundation has been given to the Joint Select Committee, the Parliament or the public for the figures that have been just hypothesised by the Government. We do not have a reliable base. In fact, Roger Clarke concludes that the proposition that the Government's estimates of savings, whether over a year or over 10 years, should be accepted on the basis of such flimsy justification strains credibility to breaking point. This is not just another member of the public making a statement about the foundations for the Government's estimates; he is a careful and responsible reader in information technology at the ANU, a person who made to the parliamentary inquiry a submission which was about an inch thick and most carefully put together. I have not heard from any Government member a critique of any inadequacy in that submission. I have not heard any Government rebuttal of the flimsy basis that I have just described. So it is fair for the Senate and the public to place little credibility on the Government's figures. I reiterate the conclusion on the first vital point that we cannot be assured that any net savings will accrue at all.

The Government does not appear to have taken into account other costs that are involved. According to figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, 15 per cent of the Australian population change address within a State each year and a further 1.7 per cent move interstate. When allowances for family movements and international movements are taken into account, the estimates range upwards of 20 per cent. The cost and complexity of keeping up with these movements would be enormous. Twenty per cent of the Australia Cards would need to be updated every year. This would involve an enormous additional cost, quite apart from the arrangements that would need to be made by those families and individuals.

The Opposition has said many times that it will support any reasonable legislation that will combat tax evasion and welfare fraud. The fact is that a desired crackdown can be achieved at a fraction of the cost and in a way which will not infringe civil liberties. The opportunities are already before this Government without the need for this legislation. The Opposition has addressed itself to this task.
